item.dc:title: Activation of CS2 and CO2 by Silylium Cations

item.title: How does bridging core modification alter the photovoltaic characteristics of triphenylamine‐based hole transport materials? Theoretical understanding and prediction
item.dc:description: Perovskite solar cells have gained immense interest of researchers owing to their high photophysical properties, low‐cost production, and high power conversion efficiencies. Hole transport materials (HTMs) play a dominant role in enhancing the power conversion efficiencies (PCE), and long length diffusion of hole and electron in perovskite solar cells. In hole transport materials, modification of π‐linkers is proved to be an efficient approach for enhancing the overall PCE of perovskite solar cells. In this work, π‐linker modification of recently synthesized H‐Bi molecule ( R ) is done with novel π‐linkers. After structural modifications, ten novel HTMs ( HB1‐HB10 ) having D‐π‐D backbone have been obtained. Structural‐property relationship, optoelectronic and photovoltaic characteristics of newly designed hole transport materials are comprehensively examined and compared with reference molecule. In addition, different geometric parameters are also examined with assist of density functional theory and time dependent‐density functional theory. All designed molecules exhibit narrow HOMO‐LUMO energy gap (E g =2.82‐2.99 eV) as compared to R molecule (E g =3.05 eV). Designed molecules expressed red‐shifting in absorption spectra with low values of excitation energy which in return offer high power conversion efficiencies. Results of all analysis advocate that these novel designed HTMs are ideal aspirant for construction of future high performance perovskite solar cells.
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Ramzan Saeed Ashraf Janjua
item.content:encoded: Perovskite solar cells have gained immense interest of researchers owing to their high photophysical properties, low‐cost production, and high power conversion efficiencies. Hole transport materials (HTMs) play a dominant role in enhancing the power conversion efficiencies (PCE), and long length diffusion of hole and electron in perovskite solar cells. In hole transport materials, modification of π‐linkers is proved to be an efficient approach for enhancing the overall PCE of perovskite solar cells. In this work, π‐linker modification of recently synthesized H‐Bi molecule ( R ) is done with novel π‐linkers. After structural modifications, ten novel HTMs ( HB1‐HB10 ) having D‐π‐D backbone have been obtained. Structural‐property relationship, optoelectronic and photovoltaic characteristics of newly designed hole transport materials are comprehensively examined and compared with reference molecule. In addition, different geometric parameters are also examined with assist of density functional theory and time dependent‐density functional theory. All designed molecules exhibit narrow HOMO‐LUMO energy gap (E g =2.82‐2.99 eV) as compared to R molecule (E g =3.05 eV). Designed molecules expressed red‐shifting in absorption spectra with low values of excitation energy which in return offer high power conversion efficiencies. Results of all analysis advocate that these novel designed HTMs are ideal aspirant for construction of future high performance perovskite solar cells.
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Accepted Article.
item.dc:title: How does bridging core modification alter the photovoltaic characteristics of triphenylamine‐based hole transport materials? Theoretical understanding and prediction

item.title: Doubling Förster Resonance Energy Transfer Efficiency in Proteins with Extrinsic Thioamide Probes: Implications to Thiomodified Nucleobases
item.dc:description: Designing potential protein‐ligand pair is pivotal not only to track protein structure, dynamics but also to assist in atomistic understanding of drug delivery. Here we report the potentiality of a small model thioamide probe that can be used to study albumin proteins. Monitoring Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) dynamics with the help of fluorescence spectroscopic techniques, we observed two‐fold enhancement in the FRET efficiency in the case of 2‐Thiopyridone (2TPY) compared to its amide analog. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulation depicts the relative position of the free energy minima to be quite stable in case of 2TPY via non‐covalent interactions with sulfur which helps for enhancement in the FRET efficiency. Finally, we showed its application by pairing thiouracils with protein. We found that site‐selective sulfur atom substitution approach and non‐covalent interactions with sulfur can substantially enhance the FRET efficiency which can be a potential avenue to explore for designing FRET probes to study structure and dynamics of biomolecules.
item.dc:creator: Subhrakant Jena, Kiran Devi Tulsiyan, Rajiv K. Kar, Hemanta K. Kisan, Himansu Sekhar Biswal

item.title: The aggregation pattern of Aβ1‐40 is altered by the presence of N‐truncated Aβ4‐40 and/or Cu(II) ions in a similar way via ionic interactions
item.dc:description: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is one of the most common multifactorial diseases characterized by a range of abnormal molecular processes such as the accumulation of extracellular plaques containing the amyloid‐β (Aβ) peptides and dyshomeostasis of copper in the brain. Herein, we investigate the effect of Cu(II) ions on the aggregation of Aβ1‐40, and Aβ4‐40, representing two most prevalent families of Aβ peptides, full length and N‐truncated ones. Both families are similarly abundant in healthy and AD brains. In either of the studied peptides, substoichiometric Cu(II) concentrations accelerated aggregation, while superstoichiometric Cu(II) inhibited the fibril formation, likely by stabilizing oligomers. The addition of either Aβ4‐40 or substoichiometric Cu(II) ions affected the aggregation profile of Aβ1‐40, by yielding shorter and thicker fibrils. The similarity of these two effects can be attributed to the increase of positive charge at the Aβ N‐terminus, which is caused either by Cu(II) complexation or N‐truncation at position 4. Our findings provide a better understanding of the biological Aβ aggregation process as these two Aβ species and Cu(II) ions coexist and interact under physiological conditions.
item.dc:creator: Ewelina Stefaniak, Elena Atrian-Blasco, Wojciech Goch, Laurent Sabater, Christelle Hureau, Wojciech Bal
